commander.name: Général de brigade Marie-Pierre Koenig
commander.previous_service: Promoted to Brigadier General July 1941, commanded Free French forces in North Africa

personnel_composition.note: Force composed of French Foreign Legion, French Marines, Colonial troops from Chad, Congo, Senegal, Madagascar, Central Africa, and Pacific territories

1.note: Primary French service rifle, some supplemented by British Lee-Enfield and American M1917

2.note: Standard French squad automatic weapon, preferred by troops over BAR

3.note: Medium/heavy machine gun for sustained fire support

tanks.note: No tanks assigned - Brigade relied on infantry and artillery. British-supplied Bren Carriers provided limited armored support.

halftracks.note: No halftracks - Brigade used trucks for motorized transport

armored_cars.note: No traditional armored cars - Bren Carriers served reconnaissance role

Universal Carrier (Bren).note: Light armored tracked vehicles, provided mobility and limited protection

trucks.note: Mix of British-supplied and French legacy vehicles

support_vehicles.note: Support functions integrated into truck fleet

Canon de 75 mle 1897.note: Famous French 75mm gun - 30 used in anti-tank role, 24 as field artillery

anti_tank.note: 30 of the 75mm guns also served in anti-tank role, included in field artillery count

Hotchkiss M1914 (AA mount).note: Infantry MGs adaptable to AA role

note_aircraft: No organic air assets - Relied on British RAF support

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for static defense. Bir Hakeim defensive position stocked with 20,000 rounds of 75mm ammunition, 10 days food. Supply lines through British 8th Army. Mix of French and British equipment complicated logistics.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1942-Q2 (April-June) - Late spring/Early summer in North Africa
weather_environment.terrain_type: Desert and rocky plateau (Bir Hakeim position, southern Gazala Line)

subordinate_units.composition: Two battalions of French Foreign Legion
subordinate_units.note: Elite French Foreign Legion unit, core of Free French fighting strength
Later merged with Marine Infantry after Bir Hakeim
French Colonial forces from North Africa
Operated the 54x 75mm guns and anti-tank weapons

tactical_doctrine.role: Fixed defensive position, anchor of Gazala Line southern flank
tactical_innovations: Effective use of 75mm guns in dual field/anti-tank role
Layered defensive positions at Bir Hakeim
Integration of limited armored vehicles (Bren Carriers) for counter-attacks
known_issues: Lack of tanks limited offensive capability
Limited heavy artillery compared to Axis forces
Mix of French and British equipment complicated logistics
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Troops adapted to desert conditions through service in Syria/Levant. Vehicles modified for sand and heat. Water discipline critical.

battle_honors: Battle of Bir Hakeim (26 May - 11 June 1942)
historical_context.operational_history: 1st Free French Brigade reorganized from 1st Light Free French Division in December 1941 to conform to British organization. Assigned to British 8th Army and deployed to Gazala Line. Defended Bir Hakeim against Rommel's Afrika Korps for 16 days, delaying Axis offensive and enabling British forces to regroup. 2,700 of 3,700 troops successfully evacuated after ordered withdrawal on 11 June 1942.
historical_context.significance: Bir Hakeim demonstrated Free French military capability and restored French military honor after 1940 defeat. Earned respect from British allies and international recognition.

special_rules: Stubborn Defense: +1 morale in defensive positions
